name: 2-chloro-3,6-difluorophenol
Reason: 2-chloro-3,6-difluorophenol has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The introduction of two fluorine atoms increases the molecular weight and size, which raises the melting point. The chlorine atom introduces a dipole moment, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and rigidify the structure, estimated at around +10°C. The fluorine atoms also increase the molecular weight and size, which raises the melting point. The presence of two fluorine atoms can also increase the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and rigidity.
